pullRequest.body:
Adding equivalence between OnePoint K and projective line over K, as discussed at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/.E2.9C.94.20Projective.20extended.20real.20line/near/463620378
The [first PR for this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16152) became unable to automatically merge, so I am closing it and opening up this one.
(I do have a proof extending this to a homeomorphism for K = Real, but perhaps it is more disciplined to do the Equiv first?)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [1252acb7c3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17266/commits/1252acb7c3de867019d90b585b418b014fe17a6b)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Compactification.OnePointEquiv`|1241|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ equivProjectivization`
`+ equivProjectivization_apply_coe`
`+ equivProjectivization_apply_infinity`
`+ equivProjectivization_symm_apply_mk`
`+ lift`
`+ lift_mk`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
I've nothing against `simp_all`, but here it seems easy to replace it with standard `simp`, so I did it.

Thanks for doing this, I'm happy this work is on its way to Mathlib üéâ

 I'm afraid I won't have time to have a close look until the weekend. For now I just have some passing comments:

1.  The way I think about this is that if $V$ is a vector space then a choice of codimension-one affine subspace $H$ which does not contain the origin induces a bijection $‚ÑôV \simeq H ‚äî ‚ÑôH$ (according to whether a line in $V$ meets $H$ or not). In the case that $V$ is two-dimensional, this means $H$ is one-dimensional and so $H$ is a line and $‚ÑôH$ is a point. I can't help wondering if we might be able to simplify some of the proofs here by factoring them through this more abstract approach.
2. Notwithstanding the above, I admit it is may be worth giving special attention to situation (currently proposed) where $V$ is the plane and $H$ is the horizontal line through $(0, 1)$.
3. It looks like some of the results require `Field K` where `DivisionRing K` should work? This is not just Mathlib silliness: I think it is important that we can cover the case of the quaternionic projective line.

Anyway as I say, I'll return at the weekend and give do some proper feedback, and in the meantime, thanks again.
Thanks @ocfnash for the encouragement! I'm a bit tied up now but looking forward to thinking more about this.

@ocfnash Does it look okay now? Generalizing to division rings worked out nicely so thanks for suggesting that.
Regarding your comment (1) above, $‚ÑôV \simeq H ‚äî ‚ÑôH$, what is the bijection you have in mind?

Sorry I've been so slow getting back to this, I'll try hard to prioritise it tomorrow evening.

> Does it look okay now?

It looks good but I there are a few points I'd like to address. E.g., I think there is a moderate amount of room for golfing. I also note that various definitions like `divOnePoint` and `divOnePoint'` are really just implementation details en route to `divSlope_equiv` so shouldn't really be exposed. Also everything is in the root namespace and the notation `√∑` is global üò± 

> Generalizing to division rings worked out nicely so thanks for suggesting that.

Great, thanks for taking up the suggestion!

> Regarding your comment (1) above, ‚Ñô V ‚âÉ H ‚äî ‚Ñô H , what is the bijection you have in mind?

I think we can live without this, but since you mentioned it, I was trying to sketch the bijection with the remark "according to whether a line in V meets H or not". The idea is that if `H` is a codimension-one affine plane (with distinguished point acting as origin) inside `V`, then the lines in `V` (i.e., the points of `‚Ñô V`) fall into two classes: those that intersect `H` and those that do not (i.e., they're parallel to `H`). Each line in the first class is uniquely determined by its point of intersection with `H` and so we can identify this subset of `‚Ñô V` with `H`. The lines in the second class each uniquely determine a line in `H` by translating the origin of `V` to the distinguished point of `H`. So we can identify these parallel lines with lines in `H`, i.e., with `‚Ñô H`. So that's the bijection (and the inductive construction of projective space).

> It looks good but I there are a few points I'd like to address. E.g., I think there is a moderate amount of room for golfing. I also note that various definitions like `divOnePoint` and `divOnePoint'` are really just implementation details en route to `divSlope_equiv` so shouldn't really be exposed. Also everything is in the root namespace and the notation `√∑` is global üò±
> 

Sorry about that, I've put everything except `divSlope_equiv` in a namespace `OnePointEquiv` now. I don't know if that's the proper way.

> > Regarding your comment (1) above, ‚Ñô V ‚âÉ H ‚äî ‚Ñô H , what is the bijection you have in mind?
> 
> I think we can live without this, but since you mentioned it, I was trying to sketch the bijection with the remark "according to whether a line in V meets H or not". The idea is that if `H` is a codimension-one affine plane (with distinguished point acting as origin) inside `V`, then the lines in `V` (i.e., the points of `‚Ñô V`) fall into two classes: those that intersect `H` and those that do not (i.e., they're parallel to `H`). Each line in the first class is uniquely determined by its point of intersection with `H` and so we can identify this subset of `‚Ñô V` with `H`. The lines in the second class each uniquely determine a line in `H` by translating the origin of `V` to the distinguished point of `H`. So we can identify these parallel lines with lines in `H`, i.e., with `‚Ñô H`. So that's the bijection (and the inductive construction of projective space).

Ah okay, I see the picture now.
It would be nice to eventually add a proof that `divSlope` is a homeomorphism in the case of ‚Ñù.
I have completed and formalized such a proof, although I wouldn't say it's Mathlib-level yet.
So, one question is whether your map also is a homeomorphism.

> one question is whether your map also is a homeomorphism.

Just to answer this question from [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17266#issuecomment-2430525234): yes, the map I describe is a homeomorphism. In fact it's the same map if you take `H` to be the horizontal line through `(0, 1)`.

> 
> Thank you again for this work. I look forward to the follow up proving we have a homeomorphism.

Thanks for the rewrite! Yes I look forward to submitting a follow-up although my proof there is quite tedious :)

> > Thank you again for this work. I look forward to the follow up proving we have a homeomorphism.
> 
> Thanks for the rewrite! Yes I look forward to submitting a follow-up although my proof there is quite tedious :)

It looks like the proof that projective space is compact is missing. I think if you first add this then you should be able to prove the map is a homeomorphism by using the universal property of one-point compactification.

I'm happy with this now but because I ended up writing quite a lot of this I'll have to ask another maintainer to review instead of merging it myself.

Thanks again!

LGTM, thanks!

bors merge

Build failed:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11496461997/job/31998122071)

Can you please merge master, fix the error and merge it? Thanks!

bors d+

:v: bjoernkjoshanssen can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Build failed:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11504340648/job/32023613138)
You have to merge master (and fix the error) before merging it.

> You have to merge master (and fix the error) before merging it.

Oops, sorry. There's no red "merge conflict" tag and everything looks fine in VSCode, so I don't know what's causing the error. What exactly do you mean by "merge master"?

Something changed in mathlib since the moment you opened the PR, and now your proofs don't work anymore, so you have to update mathlib (by merging `origin/master` to your branch, I just did it). It is nothing strange, it happens all the time. Most likely it is just a lemma that changed name or something like that.
I've fixed the error, when it's green you can merge it.

> I've fixed the error, when it's green you can merge it.

Thanks!
I was thinking of doing `git pull origin master` in my local copy, but I'm not sure if that's equivalent to merging `master` into `origin/bjoernkjoshanssen_onepoint`.
bors r+

> > I've fixed the error, when it's green you can merge it.
> 
> Thanks! I was thinking of doing `git pull origin master` in my local copy, but I'm not sure if that's equivalent to merging `master` into `origin/bjoernkjoshanssen_onepoint`.

It's `git fetch` (or equivalent, to get the laster master) and then `git merge origin/master`

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11505774517/job/32028233091)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11505774517/job/32028232228)

> 
> It looks like the proof that projective space is compact is missing. I think if you first add this then you should be able to prove the map is a homeomorphism by using the universal property of one-point compactification.
> 

I just was reminded that my proof does include:
`instance {n:‚Ñï} : CompactSpace (‚Ñô ‚Ñù (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù))`
But I'm just using it to be able to invoke `Continuous.homeoOfEquivCompactToT2`.
Is this universal property you allude to in Mathlib already?

> > It looks like the proof that projective space is compact is missing. I think if you first add this then you should be able to prove the map is a homeomorphism by using the universal property of one-point compactification.
> 
> I just was reminded that my proof does include: `instance {n:‚Ñï} : CompactSpace (‚Ñô ‚Ñù (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù))` But I'm just using it to be able to invoke `Continuous.homeoOfEquivCompactToT2`. Is this universal property you allude to in Mathlib already?

`Continuous.homeoOfEquivCompactToT2` is certainly relevant but it's not what I had in mind. I decided to write a reply [on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Projective.20extended.20real.20line/near/479252033) for greater visibility. Hopefully I got it correct!
Can you use a little bit less `simp_all`? `simp only` is probably enough here.
I think we need to make sure this works for division rings. I've had a quick look and suggested what I think is the appropriate modification.
LGTM, thanks!

Thank you very much for taking this up. I have finally had time to take a close look.

Even though this is very nice work, I have quite a few suggestions. Some of these are just aspects of Mathlib style that there is no way to know in advance. Some detailed high-level remarks are as follows:
 1. Using `open Classical` is almost always undesirable, and is undesirable here. We should use `[DecidableEq K]` instead here. (I will omit the detailed explanation for now, but can provide it upon request.)
 2. Almost all the definitions / lemmas are auxiliary to the main construction with no value once you have `divSlope_equiv`. If possible we should thus avoid creating them.
 3. I think we should use `K √ó K` instead of `Fin 2 ‚Üí K` because this is more convenient and the result does not generalise beyond dimension two (more precisely it generalises in a different direction: to spheres, rather than projective spaces).
 4. When authoring a new definition like `divSlope_equiv` we should almost always create API that defines its behaviour so that downstream users do not have to unfold its definition.
 5. The lemma `rev_div_assoc` is not necessary but would have had to go in a different file if it were --- we always try to group lemmas in the most appropriate file.
 6. We should not create a global notation `√∑` for this very specific situation, especially as it is really just an implementation detail en route to `divSlope_equiv`.
 7. The name `divSlope_equiv` should be camelCase and is too opaque for global namespace.
 8. Part of the reason you have to work so hard here is that the `Projectivization` definition is missing some API. There should be a `Projectivization.lift` definition to help for situations like this.

etc.

With all of the above in mind, I propose that you add the following to `LinearAlgebra.Projectivization.Basic` (maybe just above the definition `protected noncomputable def rep`):
```lean
/-- A function on non-zero vectors which is independent of scale, descends to a function on the
projectivization. -/
protected def lift {Œ± : Type*} (f : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 } ‚Üí Œ±)
    (hf : ‚àÄ (a b : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 }) (t : K), a = t ‚Ä¢ (b : V) ‚Üí f a = f b)
    (x : ‚Ñô K V) : Œ± :=
  Quotient.lift f (by rintro ‚ü®-, hv‚ü© ‚ü®w, hw‚ü© ‚ü®‚ü®t, -‚ü©, rfl‚ü©; exact hf ‚ü®_, hv‚ü© ‚ü®w, hw‚ü© t rfl) x

@[simp]
protected lemma lift_mk {Œ± : Type*} (f : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 } ‚Üí Œ±)
    (hf : ‚àÄ (a b : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 }) (t : K), a = t ‚Ä¢ (b : V) ‚Üí f a = f b)
    (v : V) (hv : v ‚â† 0) :
    Projectivization.lift f hf (mk K v hv) = f ‚ü®v, hv‚ü© :=
  rfl
```
and then using that the entire contents of your file can be replaced with:
```lean
open scoped LinearAlgebra.Projectivization OnePoint
open Projectivization

namespace OnePoint

variable (K : Type*) [DivisionRing K] [DecidableEq K]

def equivProjectivization :
    OnePoint K ‚âÉ ‚Ñô K (K √ó K) where
  toFun p := Option.elim p (mk K (1, 0) (by simp)) (fun t ‚Ü¶ mk K (t, 1) (by simp))
  invFun p := by
    refine Projectivization.lift
      (fun u : {v : K √ó K // v ‚â† 0} ‚Ü¶ if u.1.2 ‚â† 0 then ((u.1.2)‚Åª¬π * u.1.1) else ‚àû) ?_ p
    rintro ‚ü®-, hv‚ü© ‚ü®‚ü®x, y‚ü©, hw‚ü© t rfl
    have ht : t ‚â† 0 := by rintro rfl; simp at hv
    by_cases h‚ÇÄ : y = 0 <;> simp [h‚ÇÄ, ht, mul_assoc]
  left_inv p := by cases p <;> simp [OnePoint.infty, OnePoint.some]
  right_inv p := by
    induction' p using ind with p hp
    obtain ‚ü®x, y‚ü© := p
    by_cases h‚ÇÄ : y = 0 <;>
    simp only [Option.elim, ite_not, Projectivization.lift_mk, h‚ÇÄ, mk_eq_mk_iff]
    ¬∑ have h‚ÇÄ' : x ‚â† 0 := by aesop
      exact ‚ü®Units.mk0 _ (inv_ne_zero h‚ÇÄ'), by simp [h‚ÇÄ']‚ü©
    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®Units.mk0 _ (inv_ne_zero h‚ÇÄ), by simp [h‚ÇÄ]‚ü©

@[simp]
lemma equivProjectivization_apply_infinity :
    equivProjectivization K ‚àû = mk K ‚ü®1, 0‚ü© (by simp) :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma equivProjectivization_apply_coe (t : K) :
    equivProjectivization K t = mk K ‚ü®t, 1‚ü© (by simp) :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma equivProjectivization_symm_apply_mk (x y : K) (h : (x, y) ‚â† 0) :
    (equivProjectivization K).symm (mk K ‚ü®x, y‚ü© h) = if y = 0 then ‚àû else y‚Åª¬π * x := by
  simp [equivProjectivization]

end OnePoint
```

Thank you again for this work. I look forward to the follow up proving we have a homeomorphism.
This works for any `K` with `[Zero K]  [Div K]` (not very interesting in general, but why not).
Thanks, fixed.
Can you modify the statement without using `fun`, but having variables before the `:`? Also,
Thanks, yes there was a superfluous function application which I've removed now.
Nonterminal `simp`.
Fixed.
Please try to avoid `unfold`. If you really need it, just write the corresponding `rfl` lemma (here I guess it is enough to put `divOnePoint` inside the `simp only` call).
Ah, I didn't know about putting the unfolding inside the `simp` call, thanks.
Nonterminal `simp`.
This one seems to be terminal.
Can you replace the `show` with a `rw`?
Thanks, now I've changed `m` to `m.1` in the statement of the theorem to avoid having to write `show`.
Here `a` can be implicit. Also, the name should mention something like `snd` (and if we keep this we also want the other one).
Good point, I've restructured that part of the file to make it simpler/more elegant.

This proof seems a little bit over complicated. For example
```lean
lemma not_both_zero [Zero K]
    (a : Fin 2 ‚Üí K) (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : a 1 = 0) : a 0 ‚â† 0 :=
  fun H ‚Ü¶ ha <| funext fun x ‚Ü¶ by fin_cases x <;> simp [h, H]
```
works. Maybe this is even *too* golfed, but `fin_cases` is surely a good idea.
Great, I didn't know about `fin_cases` (and now I realize I could have used it many times in the past).
I think it is better to make this instance `local`.
Actually that instance is not needed so I just removed it.
We usually avoid implications in lemma statement (just write the assumption before the colon).
Thanks, fixed now.
Instead of `unfold` please write a `rfl` lemma and rewrite it.
Fixed
Same.
Fixed
Can `fin_cases` simplify the proof?
Yes! Done
Can you explicit mark this using the `TODO` keywork? In that way it is less likely we forget to remove the comment once it is done.
OK, I wrote "TODO:" there.
Can you state `h` using a `‚àÄ` instead of the function? It seems more natural.
Actually it can be simply `c ‚Ä¢ b.1 = a.1`; anyway, thanks for noticing that something was off there.
This can surely go in a much more basic file (note that `Fin` is defined before mathlib, but just find a mathlbi file that works)?

Hmm... is it okay to just incorporate the proof `funext fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp[hc,ga]` where the lemma is used, like this?
```
      have : a.1 0 ‚â† 0 := fun hc => .elim <|a.2 <|funext fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp[hc,ga]
      have : b.1 0 ‚â† 0 := fun hc => .elim <|b.2 <|funext fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp[hc,gb]
```

```suggestion
  funext <| fun j => by fin_cases j <;> simp [h‚ÇÄ,h‚ÇÅ]
```

```suggestion
    ¬∑ simp [divSlope, divOnePoint, ga, gb] at h
```

```suggestion
    ¬∑ simp [divSlope, divOnePoint, ga, gb] at h
```

```suggestion
      ¬∑ simp only [divSlope, divOnePoint, ite_not, Quotient.lift_mk, smul_eq_mul, ga, gb] at h
```

```suggestion
        field_simp  at h' ‚ä¢
```
Oh so the ‚ä¢ means "at the goal too". Didn't know about that... seems useful.

```suggestion
      ¬∑ simp [h, ga, gb]
```

```suggestion
lemma divSlope_surjective [Field K] : Function.Surjective (@divSlope K _) :=
```
Sure

If we want this setup to work in the non-commutative setting (i.e., for `[DivisionRing K]` instead of `[Field K]`) then this should be:
```suggestion
noncomputable def divOnePoint [Zero K] [Inv K] [Mul K] (a : K) (r : K) : OnePoint K :=
  if r ‚â† 0 then r‚Åª¬π * a else ‚àû
```
OK, got it to work, no more mentions of `Field`.
Maybe this can be removed? I guess the point is to use the equivalence rather than the bare function.
Good idea... done

Fully qualifying names in doc comments makes links work in our [HTML docs](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/)
```suggestion
* `OnePoint.equivProjectivization` : the equivalence `OnePoint K ‚âÉ ‚Ñô K (K √ó K)`.
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Equivalence between OnePoint K and projective line over field K

Can you use a little bit less `simp_all`? `simp only` is probably enough here.
I've nothing against `simp_all`, but here it seems easy to replace it with standard `simp`, so I did it.

Thanks for doing this, I'm happy this work is on its way to Mathlib üéâ

 I'm afraid I won't have time to have a close look until the weekend. For now I just have some passing comments:

1.  The way I think about this is that if $V$ is a vector space then a choice of codimension-one affine subspace $H$ which does not contain the origin induces a bijection $‚ÑôV \simeq H ‚äî ‚ÑôH$ (according to whether a line in $V$ meets $H$ or not). In the case that $V$ is two-dimensional, this means $H$ is one-dimensional and so $H$ is a line and $‚ÑôH$ is a point. I can't help wondering if we might be able to simplify some of the proofs here by factoring them through this more abstract approach.
2. Notwithstanding the above, I admit it is may be worth giving special attention to situation (currently proposed) where $V$ is the plane and $H$ is the horizontal line through $(0, 1)$.
3. It looks like some of the results require `Field K` where `DivisionRing K` should work? This is not just Mathlib silliness: I think it is important that we can cover the case of the quaternionic projective line.

Anyway as I say, I'll return at the weekend and give do some proper feedback, and in the meantime, thanks again.
Thanks @ocfnash for the encouragement! I'm a bit tied up now but looking forward to thinking more about this.
I think we need to make sure this works for division rings. I've had a quick look and suggested what I think is the appropriate modification.

Regarding your comment (1) above, $‚ÑôV \simeq H ‚äî ‚ÑôH$, what is the bijection you have in mind?
LGTM, thanks!

Sorry I've been so slow getting back to this, I'll try hard to prioritise it tomorrow evening.

> Does it look okay now?

It looks good but I there are a few points I'd like to address. E.g., I think there is a moderate amount of room for golfing. I also note that various definitions like `divOnePoint` and `divOnePoint'` are really just implementation details en route to `divSlope_equiv` so shouldn't really be exposed. Also everything is in the root namespace and the notation `√∑` is global üò± 

> Generalizing to division rings worked out nicely so thanks for suggesting that.

Great, thanks for taking up the suggestion!

> Regarding your comment (1) above, ‚Ñô V ‚âÉ H ‚äî ‚Ñô H , what is the bijection you have in mind?

I think we can live without this, but since you mentioned it, I was trying to sketch the bijection with the remark "according to whether a line in V meets H or not". The idea is that if `H` is a codimension-one affine plane (with distinguished point acting as origin) inside `V`, then the lines in `V` (i.e., the points of `‚Ñô V`) fall into two classes: those that intersect `H` and those that do not (i.e., they're parallel to `H`). Each line in the first class is uniquely determined by its point of intersection with `H` and so we can identify this subset of `‚Ñô V` with `H`. The lines in the second class each uniquely determine a line in `H` by translating the origin of `V` to the distinguished point of `H`. So we can identify these parallel lines with lines in `H`, i.e., with `‚Ñô H`. So that's the bijection (and the inductive construction of projective space).

> It looks good but I there are a few points I'd like to address. E.g., I think there is a moderate amount of room for golfing. I also note that various definitions like `divOnePoint` and `divOnePoint'` are really just implementation details en route to `divSlope_equiv` so shouldn't really be exposed. Also everything is in the root namespace and the notation `√∑` is global üò±
> 

Sorry about that, I've put everything except `divSlope_equiv` in a namespace `OnePointEquiv` now. I don't know if that's the proper way.

> > Regarding your comment (1) above, ‚Ñô V ‚âÉ H ‚äî ‚Ñô H , what is the bijection you have in mind?
> 
> I think we can live without this, but since you mentioned it, I was trying to sketch the bijection with the remark "according to whether a line in V meets H or not". The idea is that if `H` is a codimension-one affine plane (with distinguished point acting as origin) inside `V`, then the lines in `V` (i.e., the points of `‚Ñô V`) fall into two classes: those that intersect `H` and those that do not (i.e., they're parallel to `H`). Each line in the first class is uniquely determined by its point of intersection with `H` and so we can identify this subset of `‚Ñô V` with `H`. The lines in the second class each uniquely determine a line in `H` by translating the origin of `V` to the distinguished point of `H`. So we can identify these parallel lines with lines in `H`, i.e., with `‚Ñô H`. So that's the bijection (and the inductive construction of projective space).

Ah okay, I see the picture now.
It would be nice to eventually add a proof that `divSlope` is a homeomorphism in the case of ‚Ñù.
I have completed and formalized such a proof, although I wouldn't say it's Mathlib-level yet.
So, one question is whether your map also is a homeomorphism.

Thank you very much for taking this up. I have finally had time to take a close look.

Even though this is very nice work, I have quite a few suggestions. Some of these are just aspects of Mathlib style that there is no way to know in advance. Some detailed high-level remarks are as follows:
 1. Using `open Classical` is almost always undesirable, and is undesirable here. We should use `[DecidableEq K]` instead here. (I will omit the detailed explanation for now, but can provide it upon request.)
 2. Almost all the definitions / lemmas are auxiliary to the main construction with no value once you have `divSlope_equiv`. If possible we should thus avoid creating them.
 3. I think we should use `K √ó K` instead of `Fin 2 ‚Üí K` because this is more convenient and the result does not generalise beyond dimension two (more precisely it generalises in a different direction: to spheres, rather than projective spaces).
 4. When authoring a new definition like `divSlope_equiv` we should almost always create API that defines its behaviour so that downstream users do not have to unfold its definition.
 5. The lemma `rev_div_assoc` is not necessary but would have had to go in a different file if it were --- we always try to group lemmas in the most appropriate file.
 6. We should not create a global notation `√∑` for this very specific situation, especially as it is really just an implementation detail en route to `divSlope_equiv`.
 7. The name `divSlope_equiv` should be camelCase and is too opaque for global namespace.
 8. Part of the reason you have to work so hard here is that the `Projectivization` definition is missing some API. There should be a `Projectivization.lift` definition to help for situations like this.

etc.

With all of the above in mind, I propose that you add the following to `LinearAlgebra.Projectivization.Basic` (maybe just above the definition `protected noncomputable def rep`):
```lean
/-- A function on non-zero vectors which is independent of scale, descends to a function on the
projectivization. -/
protected def lift {Œ± : Type*} (f : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 } ‚Üí Œ±)
    (hf : ‚àÄ (a b : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 }) (t : K), a = t ‚Ä¢ (b : V) ‚Üí f a = f b)
    (x : ‚Ñô K V) : Œ± :=
  Quotient.lift f (by rintro ‚ü®-, hv‚ü© ‚ü®w, hw‚ü© ‚ü®‚ü®t, -‚ü©, rfl‚ü©; exact hf ‚ü®_, hv‚ü© ‚ü®w, hw‚ü© t rfl) x

@[simp]
protected lemma lift_mk {Œ± : Type*} (f : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 } ‚Üí Œ±)
    (hf : ‚àÄ (a b : { v : V // v ‚â† 0 }) (t : K), a = t ‚Ä¢ (b : V) ‚Üí f a = f b)
    (v : V) (hv : v ‚â† 0) :
    Projectivization.lift f hf (mk K v hv) = f ‚ü®v, hv‚ü© :=
  rfl
```
and then using that the entire contents of your file can be replaced with:
```lean
open scoped LinearAlgebra.Projectivization OnePoint
open Projectivization

namespace OnePoint

variable (K : Type*) [DivisionRing K] [DecidableEq K]

def equivProjectivization :
    OnePoint K ‚âÉ ‚Ñô K (K √ó K) where
  toFun p := Option.elim p (mk K (1, 0) (by simp)) (fun t ‚Ü¶ mk K (t, 1) (by simp))
  invFun p := by
    refine Projectivization.lift
      (fun u : {v : K √ó K // v ‚â† 0} ‚Ü¶ if u.1.2 ‚â† 0 then ((u.1.2)‚Åª¬π * u.1.1) else ‚àû) ?_ p
    rintro ‚ü®-, hv‚ü© ‚ü®‚ü®x, y‚ü©, hw‚ü© t rfl
    have ht : t ‚â† 0 := by rintro rfl; simp at hv
    by_cases h‚ÇÄ : y = 0 <;> simp [h‚ÇÄ, ht, mul_assoc]
  left_inv p := by cases p <;> simp [OnePoint.infty, OnePoint.some]
  right_inv p := by
    induction' p using ind with p hp
    obtain ‚ü®x, y‚ü© := p
    by_cases h‚ÇÄ : y = 0 <;>
    simp only [Option.elim, ite_not, Projectivization.lift_mk, h‚ÇÄ, mk_eq_mk_iff]
    ¬∑ have h‚ÇÄ' : x ‚â† 0 := by aesop
      exact ‚ü®Units.mk0 _ (inv_ne_zero h‚ÇÄ'), by simp [h‚ÇÄ']‚ü©
    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®Units.mk0 _ (inv_ne_zero h‚ÇÄ), by simp [h‚ÇÄ]‚ü©

@[simp]
lemma equivProjectivization_apply_infinity :
    equivProjectivization K ‚àû = mk K ‚ü®1, 0‚ü© (by simp) :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma equivProjectivization_apply_coe (t : K) :
    equivProjectivization K t = mk K ‚ü®t, 1‚ü© (by simp) :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma equivProjectivization_symm_apply_mk (x y : K) (h : (x, y) ‚â† 0) :
    (equivProjectivization K).symm (mk K ‚ü®x, y‚ü© h) = if y = 0 then ‚àû else y‚Åª¬π * x := by
  simp [equivProjectivization]

end OnePoint
```

Thank you again for this work. I look forward to the follow up proving we have a homeomorphism.

> one question is whether your map also is a homeomorphism.

Just to answer this question from [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17266#issuecomment-2430525234): yes, the map I describe is a homeomorphism. In fact it's the same map if you take `H` to be the horizontal line through `(0, 1)`.
